pli-tv-kd2:12.4.8: Any monk who approves of designating this boundary as delimiting a may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd2:12.4.9: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:12.4.10: The Sangha has designated this boundary as delimiting a may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area, leaving out inhabited areas and the vicinity of inhabited areas.

pli-tv-kd2:12.5.1: “Monks, when you’re establishing a boundary, the boundary that defines who belongs to the same community should be established first. Afterwards you may designate the may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.2: And when you’re abolishing a boundary, the may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area should be abolished first. Afterwards you may abolish the boundary that defines who belongs to the same community.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.3: And the may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area should be abolished like this.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.4: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.5: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.6: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should abolish the existing designation of a may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.8: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.9: The Sangha abolishes the existing designation of a may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.10: Any monk who approves of abolishing this area should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.11: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.12: The Sangha has abolished the may-stay-apart-from-the-three-robes area.
pli-tv-kd2:12.5.13: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.1: And a boundary should be abolished like this.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should abolish the established monastic boundary that defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day procedure together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.6: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.7: The Sangha abolishes the established monastic boundary that defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day procedure together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.8: Any monk who approves of abolishing this boundary should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.9: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.10: The Sangha has abolished the monastic boundary that defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day procedure together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.6.11: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.1: “There are monks who live supported by inhabited areas where no boundary has been established. In these cases, the boundary of the inhabited area defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day procedure together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.2: If it is an uninhabited area in the wilderness, a distance of 80 meters on all sides defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day procedure together.
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.5: or a lake cannot form a complete boundary on its own.
pli-tv-kd2:12.7.6: In a river, in the ocean, and in a lake, the area that defines who belongs to the same community and who should do the observance-day procedure together is the distance an average man can splash water in all directions.”
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.1: At one time the monks from the group of six created a boundary that crossed an existing boundary.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.3: “The establishment of the first boundary is a legitimate legal procedure that is irreversible and fit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.4: The establishment of the subsequent boundary is an illegitimate legal procedure that is reversible and unfit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.5: You should not create boundaries that cross existing boundaries.
pli-tv-kd2:13.1.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.1: At one time the monks from the group of six enclosed one boundary within another.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.3: “The establishment of the first boundary is a legitimate legal procedure that is irreversible and fit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.4: The establishment of the subsequent boundary is an illegitimate legal procedure that is reversible and unfit to stand.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.5: You should not create boundaries that enclose existing boundaries.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:13.2.7: When you establish a boundary, you should leave a gap to any existing boundary.”
pli-tv-kd2:14.1.0: Breach of the observance-day procedure, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:14.1.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:14.1.4: “There are two observance days: the fourteenth and the fifteenth day of the month.”
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.5: The observance-day procedure that is illegitimate and has an incomplete assembly;
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.6: The observance-day procedure that is illegitimate but has a complete assembly;
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.7: The observance-day procedure that is legitimate but has an incomplete assembly;
pli-tv-kd2:14.2.8: The observance-day procedure that is legitimate and has a complete assembly.
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.3: and third of these should not be done;
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.5: The fourth should be done; I have allowed such procedures.
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.6: Therefore, monks, you should train like this:
pli-tv-kd2:14.3.7: ʻWe will do observance-day ceremonies that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.0: The recitation of the Monastic Code in brief, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.2: “How many ways of reciting the Monastic Code are there?”
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.4: “There are these five ways of reciting the Monastic Code:
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.5: After reciting the introduction, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.6: This is the first way of reciting the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.7: After reciting the introduction and the four rules entailing expulsion, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.8: This is the second way of reciting the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.9: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, and the thirteen rules entailing suspension, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.10: This is the third way of reciting the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.11: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, the thirteen rules entailing suspension, and the two undetermined rules, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-kd2:15.1.12: This is the fourth way of reciting the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.2: that the Buddha had allowed the recitation of the Monastic Code in brief,
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.3: some monks recited it in brief all the time.
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.5: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in brief.
pli-tv-kd2:15.2.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.3.1: At that time, on the observance day in a certain monastery in the Kosalan country, there was danger from savages.
pli-tv-kd2:15.3.2: The monks were not able to recite the Monastic Code in full.
pli-tv-kd2:15.3.4: “I allow you to recite the Monastic Code in brief when there are dangers.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.1: But the monks from the group of six recited the Monastic Code in brief even when there were no dangers.
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.3: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in brief when there are no dangers.
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.5: I allow you to recite the Monastic Code in brief when there are any of these dangers:
pli-tv-kd2:15.4.7: danger from kings, danger from bandits, danger from fire, danger from floods, danger from people, danger from spirits, danger from predatory animals, danger from snakes, a life-threatening danger, a danger to living the spiritual life.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six gave teachings in the midst of the Sangha without being requested.
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.3: “You should not give teachings in the midst of the Sangha without being requested.
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.5.5: I allow the most senior monk either to give a teaching himself or to request another.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.0: Discussion of questioning on the Monastic Law
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six questioned others on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.3: “You should not question others on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.5: I allow you to question others on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.6: And you should be approved like this:
pli-tv-kd2:15.6.7: either you should be approved through yourself or you should be approved through another.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.1: And how are you approved through yourself?
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, I will question so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.5: In this way you are approved through yourself.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.6: And how are you approved through another?
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.7: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.8: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.9: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, so-and-so will question so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.7.10: In this way you are approved through another.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.8.1: Soon good monks asked questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.8.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:15.8.4: “The monk who has been approved should first survey the gathering and evaluate the individuals and then ask questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.0: Discussion of replying to questions on the Monastic Law
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six replied to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.3: “You should not reply to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha without being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.5: I allow you to reply to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.6: And one should be approved like this:
pli-tv-kd2:15.9.7: either you should be approved through yourself or you should be approved through another.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.1: And how are you approved through yourself?
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, I will reply when asked by so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.5: In this way you are approved through yourself.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.6: And how are you approved through another?
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.7: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.8: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.9: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, so-and-so will reply when asked by so-and-so on the Monastic Law.’
pli-tv-kd2:15.10.10: In this way you are approved through another.”
pli-tv-kd2:15.11.1: Soon good monks replied to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha after being approved.
pli-tv-kd2:15.11.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:15.11.4: “The monk who has been approved should first survey the gathering and evaluate the individuals and then reply to questions on the Monastic Law in the midst of the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.1: At one time the monks from the group of six accused a monk of an offense without first getting his permission to do so.
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.3: “You should not accuse a monk of an offense without first getting his permission to do so.
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.5: You should only accuse someone of an offense after getting their permission:
pli-tv-kd2:16.1.6: ʻVenerable, I wish to speak to you; please give me permission.’”
pli-tv-kd2:16.2.1: Soon, after getting their permission, good monks accused the monks from the group of six of an offense.
pli-tv-kd2:16.2.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:16.2.4: “Even when you have their permission, you should first evaluate the individual and then accuse them of an offense.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.1: At this time the monks from the group of six—thinking to act before the good monks asked them for permission, but having no grounds or reasons—got permission from pure monks who had not committed any offenses.
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.3: “When you have no grounds or reasons, you should not get permission from pure monks who haven’t committed any offenses.
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:16.3.5: And you should give permission only after evaluating the individual.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.0: Objecting to an illegitimate legal procedure, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six did an illegitimate legal procedure in the midst of the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.3: “You should not do illegitimate legal procedures.
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.4.7: “You should object when an illegitimate legal procedure is being done.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.1: Soon afterwards good monks objected when the monks from the group of six did an illegitimate procedure.
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.2: The monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.4: “I allow you to just state your view.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.5.6: Once again the monks from the group of six became angry and bitter, and they made threats of violence.

pli-tv-kd2:16.6.1: On one occasion when the monks from the group of six were reciting the Monastic Code in the midst of the Sangha, they deliberately made themselves inaudible.
pli-tv-kd2:16.6.3: “When reciting the Monastic Code, you should not deliberately make yourselves inaudible.
pli-tv-kd2:16.6.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.1: At one time Venerable Udāyī was the Sangha’s reciter of the Monastic Code, but he had a hoarse voice.
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.3: that the Buddha had laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.4: that the reciter of the Monastic Code should make themselves heard, and he thought, ʻI have a hoarse voice, so what should I do?’
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.6: “The reciter of the Monastic Code should make an effort
pli-tv-kd2:16.7.8: If you make an effort, there’s no offense.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.8.1: On one occasion Devadatta recited the Monastic Code in a gathering that included lay people.
pli-tv-kd2:16.8.3: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in a gathering that includes lay people.
pli-tv-kd2:16.8.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.1: On one occasion the monks from the group of six recited the Monastic Code in the midst of the Sangha without being requested.
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.3: “You should not recite the Monastic Code in the midst of the Sangha without first being requested to do so.
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.5: The most senior monk should be in charge of the recitation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd2:16.9.6: The first section for recitation on ascetics of other religions is finished.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.0: Requesting the recitation of the Monastic Code, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Codanāvatthu.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.2: When he eventually arrived, he stayed there.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.3: On that occasion a number of monks were staying in a certain monastery
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.4: where the most senior monk was ignorant and incompetent.
pli-tv-kd2:17.1.5: He did not know about the observance-day or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.2: that the Buddha had laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.3: that the most senior monk should be in charge of the recitation of the Monastic Code,

pli-tv-kd2:17.2.5: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:17.2.6: “In such a case a competent and capable monk should be in charge of the recitation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.1: On one occasion on the observance day, a number of ignorant and incompetent monks were staying in a certain monastery.

pli-tv-kd2:17.3.3: They requested the most senior monk
pli-tv-kd2:17.3.7: They asked the same question of the second-most

pli-tv-kd2:17.4.4: and none of them is able to recite the Monastic Code,
pli-tv-kd2:17.5.1: they should straightaway send one monk to a neighboring monastery
pli-tv-kd2:17.5.2: to learn the Monastic Code, either in brief or in full.”

pli-tv-kd2:17.6.5: When told by the most senior monk, the junior monks did not go.

pli-tv-kd2:18.1.0: The instruction to learn the number of the lunar half-month, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.1: When he had stayed at Codanāvatthu for as long as he liked, the Buddha returned to Rājagaha.
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.2: Then, while the monks were walking for almsfood, people asked them,
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.7: “These Sakyan ascetics don’t even know the number of the lunar half-month. How then could they know anything truly useful?”
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.8: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:18.1.9: “You should learn the counting of the lunar half-months.”
pli-tv-kd2:18.2.2: “Who should learn the counting of the lunar half-months?”
pli-tv-kd2:18.2.4: “You should all learn the counting of the lunar half-months.”
pli-tv-kd2:18.3.1: On another occasion, while the monks were walking for almsfood, people asked them,
pli-tv-kd2:18.3.6: “These Sakyan ascetics don’t even know about one another. How then could they know anything truly useful?”
pli-tv-kd2:18.4.4: “You should count the monks on the observance day, either by name or by distributing tickets.”
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.1: On one occasion, not knowing that it was the observance day, monks walked for almsfood in a faraway village.
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.2: They arrived back while the Monastic Code was being recited or even just after it had been recited.
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.4: “You should announce, ʻToday is the observance day.’”
pli-tv-kd2:19.1.8: “The most senior monk should make the announcement early in the morning.”

pli-tv-kd2:19.1.11: “I allow him to make the announcement at the mealtime, too.”

pli-tv-kd2:19.1.14: “I allow him to make the announcement whenever he remembers.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.0: The instruction to do the prior duties
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.1: At one time in a certain monastery, the observance-day hall was dirty.
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.2: Newly arrived monks complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.3: “How can the resident monks not sweep the hall?”
pli-tv-kd2:20.1.4: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.4: “I allow the most senior monk to tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.5: When told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not sweep.
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.7: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to sweep, he should sweep.
pli-tv-kd2:20.2.8: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.1: On one occasion seats were not prepared in the observance-day hall.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.2: The monks sat on the ground. They became dirty, as did their robes.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.4: “You should prepare seats in the observance-day hall.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.6: “Who should prepare the seats in the hall?”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.8: “I allow the most senior monk to tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.9: When told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not prepare them.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.11: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to prepare the seats, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd2:20.3.12: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.1: On one occasion there was no lamp in the observance-day hall.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.2: Because it was dark, the monks stepped on one another and on one another’s robes.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.4: “You should light a lamp in the observance-day hall.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.6: “Who should light the lamp in the hall?”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.8: “I allow the most senior monk to tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.9: When told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not light a lamp.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.11: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to light a lamp, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd2:20.4.12: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.1: On one occasion in a certain monastery, the resident monks neither set out water for drinking nor water for washing.
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.2: Newly arrived monks complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.3: “How can the resident monks neither set out water for drinking nor water for washing?”
pli-tv-kd2:20.5.5: “You should set out water for drinking and water for washing.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.4: “I allow the most senior monk to tell a junior monk.”
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.5: When told by the senior monk, the junior monks did not set them out.
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.7: “If a monk isn’t sick and he’s told by the senior monk to set them out, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd2:20.6.8: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.0: Those going to the districts, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.1: On one occasion a number of ignorant and incompetent monks asked permission of their teachers and preceptors to go to the districts.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.3: “It may happen that a number of ignorant and incompetent monks ask permission of their teachers and preceptors to go to the districts.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.4: The teachers and preceptors should then ask them
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.5: where they’re going and whom they’re going with.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.6: If they’re going with others who are ignorant and incompetent, the teachers and preceptors shouldn’t give them permission.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.7: If they do, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:21.1.8: And if the students go without the permission of their teachers and preceptors, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.1: “It may happen that a number of ignorant and incompetent monks are staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.2: They don’t know about the observance-day or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.3: Then a monk arrives who is learned and a master of the tradition; who is an expert on the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the summaries; who is knowledgeable and competent, has a sense of conscience, and is afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.4: Those monks should treat that learned monk with kindness; they should assist him and support him, and they should attend on him with bath powder, soap, toothbrush, and water for rinsing the mouth.
pli-tv-kd2:21.2.5: If they don’t look after him in this way, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.1: “On the observance day it may happen that a number of ignorant and incompetent monks are staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.2: They don’t know about the observance-day or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.3: They should straightaway send one monk to a neighboring monastery
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.4: to learn the Monastic Code, either in brief or in full.
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.5: If he’s able to do so, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.6: If not, then those monks should all go to a monastery where the monks know about the observance-day and the observance-day procedure, about the Monastic Code and its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:21.3.7: If they don’t go, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.1: “It may happen that a number of ignorant and incompetent monks are spending the rainy-season residence in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.2: They don’t know about the observance-day or the observance-day procedure, nor about the Monastic Code or its recitation.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.3: They should straightaway send one monk to a neighboring monastery
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.4: to learn the Monastic Code, either in brief or in full.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.5: If he’s able to do so, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.6: If not, then one monk should be sent under the seven-day allowance
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.7: to learn the Monastic Code, either in brief or in full.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.8: If he’s able to do so, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.9: If not, then those monks should not spend the rainy-season residence in that monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:21.4.10: If they do, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.0: Discussion of the passing on of purity
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.1: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.2: “Gather, monks, for the Sangha to do the observance-day procedure.”
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.3: A monk said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.4: “Venerable Sir, there’s a sick monk. He hasn’t come.”
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.5: “I allow a sick monk to pass on his purity.
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.6: And it should be passed on like this.
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.7: The sick monk should approach a monk, put his upper robe over one shoulder, and squat on his heels. He should then raise his joined palms and say,
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.8: ʻI pass on my purity; please convey my purity; please announce my purity.’
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.9: If he makes this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the purity has been passed on.
pli-tv-kd2:22.1.10: If he doesn’t make this understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the purity hasn’t been passed on.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.1: If he’s able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.2: If not, then the sick monk should be brought into the midst of the Sangha together with his bed or bench. They can then do the observance-day procedure.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.3: But if the one who is nursing the sick monk says,
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.4: ʻIf we move him, his illness will get worse, or he’ll die,’ then the sick monk shouldn’t be moved.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.5: The Sangha should go to where the sick monk is and do the observance-day procedure there.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.6: But you should not do the observance-day procedure with an incomplete Sangha.
pli-tv-kd2:22.2.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.1: “If, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity departs right there, then the purity should be passed on to another.
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.2: If, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity disrobes right there,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.4: admits right there that he’s a novice monk,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.5: admits right there that he’s renounced the training,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.6: admits right there that he’s committed the worst kind of offense,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.7: admits right there that he’s insane,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.8: admits right there that he’s deranged,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.9: admits right there that he’s overwhelmed by pain,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.10: admits right there that he’s been ejected for not recognizing an offense,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.11: admits right there that he’s been ejected for not making amends for an offense,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.12: admits right there that he’s been ejected for not giving up a bad view,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.13: admits right there that he’s a paṇḍaka,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.14: admits right there that he’s living in the community by theft,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.15: admits right there that he has previously left to join the ascetics of another religion,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.16: admits right there that he’s an animal,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.17: admits right there that he’s a matricide,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.18: admits right there that he’s a patricide,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.19: admits right there that he’s a murderer of a perfected one,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.20: admits right there that he has raped a nun,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.21: admits right there that he has caused a schism in the Sangha,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.22: admits right there that he has caused the Buddha to bleed,
pli-tv-kd2:22.3.23: or admits right there that he’s a hermaphrodite, then the purity should be passed on to another.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.1: If, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity departs while on his way to the observance-day procedure, then the purity hasn’t been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.2: If, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity disrobes while on his way to the observance-day procedure …
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.3: admits that he’s a hermaphrodite while on his way to the observance-day procedure, then the purity hasn’t been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.4: But even if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity departs after reaching the Sangha, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.5: And even if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity disrobes after reaching the Sangha …
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.6: admits that he’s a hermaphrodite after reaching the Sangha, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.7: And even if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity reaches the Sangha, but doesn’t announce the purity because he falls asleep or is heedless or gains a meditation attainment, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.8: And there’s no offense for the one who is conveying the purity.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.9: And even if, after the purity has been passed on to him, the monk who is conveying the purity reaches the Sangha, but deliberately doesn’t announce the purity, then the purity has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:22.4.10: But there’s an offense of wrong conduct for the one who is conveying the purity.”
pli-tv-kd2:23.1.1: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd2:23.2.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd2:23.3.27: And even if, after the consent has been given to him, the monk who is conveying the consent departs after reaching the Sangha, then the consent has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:23.3.28: And even if, after the consent has been given to him, the monk who is conveying the consent disrobes after reaching the Sangha …
pli-tv-kd2:23.3.29: admits that he’s a hermaphrodite after reaching the Sangha, then the consent has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:23.3.30: And even if, after the consent has been given to him, the monk who is conveying the consent reaches the Sangha, but doesn’t announce the consent because he falls asleep or is heedless or gains a meditation attainment, then the consent has been brought.
pli-tv-kd2:23.3.31: And there’s no offense for the one who is conveying the consent.
pli-tv-kd2:23.3.32: And even if, after the consent has been given to him, the monk who is conveying the consent reaches the Sangha, but deliberately doesn’t announce the consent, then the consent has been brought.

pli-tv-kd2:23.3.34: On the observance day, if the Sangha has business to be done, then anyone passing on his purity should also give his consent.”
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.0: Discussion of being seized by relatives, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.1: On one occasion on the observance day, a certain monk was seized by his relatives.
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.3: “If on the observance day a monk is seized by his relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.4: other monks should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.1.5: ʻPlease release this monk for a short time, so that he can take part in the observance-day procedure.’
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.1: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.2: If not, they should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.3: ʻPlease step to one side for a moment while this monk passes on his purity.’
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.4: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.5: If not, they should say to those relatives,
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.6: ʻPlease take this monk outside the monastic boundary for a short time while the Sangha does the observance-day procedure.’
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.7: If they’re able to do this, it’s good.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.8: If not, you should not do the observance-day procedure with an incomplete Sangha.
pli-tv-kd2:24.2.9: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd2:25.1.1: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.2: “Gather, monks, there’s business for the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.3: A monk said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.4: “Venerable Sir, there’s a monk called Gagga who is insane. He hasn’t come.”
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.5: “Monks, there are two kinds of insane monks:
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.6: there is the insane monk who sometimes remembers the observance-day and sometimes doesn’t, who sometimes remembers the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes doesn’t,
pli-tv-kd2:25.1.7: who sometimes goes to the observance-day procedure and sometimes doesn’t, who sometimes goes to the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes doesn’t; and there’s the insane monk who never remembers any of this.
pli-tv-kd2:25.2.1: For the first one of these two, I allow you to give approval in regard to insanity.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.1: And it should be given like this.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.5: Sometimes he remembers the observance-day and sometimes he does not; sometimes he remembers the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he does not; sometimes he goes to the observance-day procedure and sometimes he does not; sometimes he goes to the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he does not.
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.6: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should agree on the following in regard to the insanity of the monk Gagga:
pli-tv-kd2:25.3.7: whether or not Gagga remembers either the observance-day or the legal procedures of the Sangha, whether or not he comes to either, the Sangha should do the observance-day procedure, it should do the legal procedures of the Sangha, with or without Gagga.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.3: Sometimes he remembers the observance-day procedure and sometimes he does not; sometimes he remembers the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he does not; sometimes he goes to the observance-day procedure and sometimes he does not; sometimes he goes to the legal procedures of the Sangha and sometimes he does not.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.4: The Sangha agrees on the following in regard to the insanity of the monk Gagga:
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.5: whether or not Gagga remembers either the observance-day procedure or the legal procedures of the Sangha, whether or not he comes to either, the Sangha should do the observance-day procedure, it should do the legal procedures of the Sangha, with or without Gagga.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.6: Any monk who approves of this agreement
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.8: Any monk who doesn’t approves should speak up.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.9: The Sangha has agreed in regard to the insanity of the monk Gagga.
pli-tv-kd2:25.4.11: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.0: Various kinds of observance days for the Sangha, etc.
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.1: At one time on the observance day, there were four monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.3: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.4: that the observance-day procedure should be done. But there’s only four of us. How should we do the observance-day procedure?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.5: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd2:26.1.6: “When there are four of you, you should recite the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd2:26.2.1: At one time on the observance day, there were three monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.2.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the Monastic Code should be recited when there are four. But there’s only three of us. How should we do the observance-day procedure?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.2.5: “When there are three of you, you should do the observance-day procedure by declaring your purity.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.1: And it should be done like this.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.2: A competent and capable monk should inform those monks:
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask you to listen.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.4: Today is the observance day, the fifteenth.
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.5: If it seems appropriate to the venerables, we should do the observance-day procedure by declaring purity to one another.’
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.6: The most senior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the other monks:
pli-tv-kd2:26.3.9: And he should repeat this two more times.
pli-tv-kd2:26.4.1: A junior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the other monks:
pli-tv-kd2:26.4.4: And he should repeat this two more times.”
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.1: At one time on the observance day, there were two monks staying in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the Monastic Code should be recited when there are four and that the observance-day procedure should be done by declaring purity when there are three.
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.4: But there’s only two of us.
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.5: How should we do the observance-day procedure?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.5.7: “When there are two of you, you should do the observance-day procedure by declaring your purity.
pli-tv-kd2:26.6.1: And it should be done like this:
pli-tv-kd2:26.6.2: The most senior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the junior monk:
pli-tv-kd2:26.6.5: And he should repeat this two more times.
pli-tv-kd2:26.7.1: The junior monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say to the senior monk:
pli-tv-kd2:26.7.4: And he should repeat this two more times.”
pli-tv-kd2:26.8.1: At one time on the observance day, a monk was staying in a certain monastery by himself.
pli-tv-kd2:26.8.3: “The Buddha has instructed that the Monastic Code should be recited when there are four and that the observance-day procedure should be done by declaring purity when there are two or three.
pli-tv-kd2:26.8.5: How should I do the observance-day procedure?”
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.1: “On the observance day it may happen that a monk is staying by himself in a certain monastery.
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.2: That monk should sweep whatever place the monks normally go to: whether the assembly hall, under a roof-cover, or at the foot of a tree. He should set out water for drinking and water for washing, should prepare a seat, light a lamp, and sit down.
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.3: If other monks come, he should do the observance-day procedure with them.
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.4: If not, he should determine: ʻToday is my observance day.’
pli-tv-kd2:26.9.5: If he doesn’t make a determination, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd2:26.10.1: “Wherever four monks are staying together, three shouldn’t recite the Monastic Code while one sends his purity.
